config.topic: What happened to research on automated visualization?
config.target_audience: researchers in the visualization community, they might be interested in both topic evolution and how people in the field shape the research (such as their interactions and key players)
config.domain_knowledge:
Regarding identification of automated visualization papers:

The following keywords are used to identify the automated visualization papers:
- automatic vis
- automated vis
- visualization recommendation
- mixed initiative
- mixed-initiative
- visualization generation
- vis generation
- agent

An example vega-lite filter:
test(/automatic vis|automated vis|visualization recommendation|mixed initiative|mixed-initiative|visualization generation|vis generation|agent/i, (datum.AuthorKeywords || '') + ' ' + (datum.Abstract || '') + ' ' + (datum.Title || '')) ? 'AutoVis' : 'Other'

knowledge.facts:
### Begin of facts
Top AutoVis paper: "Voyager: Exploratory Analysis via Faceted Browsing of Visualization Recommendations"
Authors: Kanit Wongsuphasawat;Dominik Moritz;Anushka Anand;Jock D. Mackinlay;Bill Howe;Jeffrey Heer
Year: 2015    Conference: InfoVis
CitationCount_CrossRef: 292
### End of facts
### Begin of facts
AutoVis papers found: 83; median citations: 14; mean citations: 30.1
Top-5 AutoVis papers (Title | Year | Conf | Citations):
- Voyager: Exploratory Analysis via Faceted Browsing of Visualization Recommendations | 2015 | InfoVis | 292
- Formalizing Visualization Design Knowledge as Constraints: Actionable and Extensible Models in Draco | 2018 | InfoVis | 177
- A Design Space of Visualization Tasks | 2013 | InfoVis | 144
- Augmenting Visualizations with Interactive Data Facts to Facilitate Interpretation and Communication | 2018 | InfoVis | 121
- FAIRVIS: Visual Analytics for Discovering Intersectional Bias in Machine Learning | 2019 | VAST | 106
### End of facts

content.text: Automated visualization (AutoVis) is a small but persistent strand within the Vis corpus: 83 AutoVis papers were detected out of 3,877 total (≈2.1%). The field has not collapsed but neither has it exploded — a gentle long-term upward slope in share (slope ≈ 0.002 share-per-year) but large year-to-year fluctuations and concentrated bursts (notably 2016, 2020, a pronounced peak in 2021 with 16 papers / 14.7% share, and another high point in 2023 with 12 papers / 9.0% share). A handful of high-impact systems papers (for example Voyager, Draco, and foundational task/design work) account for much of AutoVis’s citation footprint, while most authors contribute one or a few papers each. From these patterns we draw three high-level recommendations: (1) prioritize artifact and code release to amplify the community impact of systems work, (2) broaden and standardize evaluation practices (more user studies and shared benchmarks), and (3) program committees should explicitly reward reproducibility and interdisciplinary work to sustain healthy growth rather than ephemeral hype cycles.

content.text: The prevalence chart pairs yearly counts (bars) with a line showing AutoVis share of that year’s papers. It makes clear that AutoVis activity is intermittent: no detected AutoVis papers in many early years, first appearances in the mid-1990s, and modest upward momentum since about 2014. Over the full window there are 83 AutoVis papers out of 3,877 total. Peak activity occurred in 2021 (16 AutoVis papers, 14.7% of that year), with other notable increases in 2016 (6 papers, 5.2%) and 2020 (7 papers, 4.5%). The share line highlights how rare AutoVis work typically is — most years under 4% — and how single busy years can dominate the story. The fitted trend is slightly positive, but the year-to-year volatility warns against reading a simple steady rise: AutoVis appears to surge episodically rather than grow smoothly.

- Formalizing Visualization Design Knowledge as Constraints: Actionable and Extensible Models in Draco | 2018 | InfoVis | 177

content.text: The top-paper panel isolates the single most-cited AutoVis contribution by CrossRef citations: Voyager (2015, InfoVis) stands out with 292 CrossRef citations and is also the leading entry when using Aminer counts (487). A small group of papers concentrates influence: Draco (2018) and A Design Space of Visualization Tasks (2013) follow Voyager as highly cited AutoVis works. Across the 83 AutoVis papers the median citation is 14 and the mean around 30, indicating a skewed distribution where a few landmark systems drive the average; most AutoVis papers have modest citation counts.

visualisation.specification:
{
  "$schema": "https://vega.github.io/schema/vega-lite/v5.json",
  "description": "Analysis of AutoVis keyword matches by keyword and by field (Title, Abstract, AuthorKeywords). Bottom: sample of papers matched only by a single ambiguous keyword ('agent').",
  "vconcat": [
    {
      "title": "Counts of matches by Keyword and Field",
      "width": 700,
      "height": 360,
      "data": { "url": "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/demoPlz/mini-template/main/studio/dataset.csv", "format": { "type": "csv" } },
      "transform": [
        { "calculate": "test(/automatic\\s+vis/i, datum.Title || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "title_automatic_vis" },
        { "calculate": "test(/automatic\\s+vis/i, datum.Abstract || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "abstract_automatic_vis" },
        { "calculate": "test(/automatic\\s+vis/i, datum.AuthorKeywords || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "keywords_automatic_vis" },

        { "calculate": "test(/automated\\s+vis/i, datum.Title || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "title_automated_vis" },
        { "calculate": "test(/automated\\s+vis/i, datum.Abstract || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "abstract_automated_vis" },
        { "calculate": "test(/automated\\s+vis/i, datum.AuthorKeywords || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "keywords_automated_vis" },

        { "calculate": "test(/visualization recommendation/i, datum.Title || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "title_visualization_recommendation" },
        { "calculate": "test(/visualization recommendation/i, datum.Abstract || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "abstract_visualization_recommendation" },
        { "calculate": "test(/visualization recommendation/i, datum.AuthorKeywords || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "keywords_visualization_recommendation" },

        { "calculate": "test(/mixed[\\s-]?initiative/i, datum.Title || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "title_mixed_initiative" },
        { "calculate": "test(/mixed[\\s-]?initiative/i, datum.Abstract || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "abstract_mixed_initiative" },
        { "calculate": "test(/mixed[\\s-]?initiative/i, datum.AuthorKeywords || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "keywords_mixed_initiative" },

        { "calculate": "test(/visualization generation/i, datum.Title || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "title_visualization_generation" },
        { "calculate": "test(/visualization generation/i, datum.Abstract || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "abstract_visualization_generation" },
        { "calculate": "test(/visualization generation/i, datum.AuthorKeywords || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "keywords_visualization_generation" },

        { "calculate": "test(/vis generation/i, datum.Title || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "title_vis_generation" },
        { "calculate": "test(/vis generation/i, datum.Abstract || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "abstract_vis_generation" },
        { "calculate": "test(/vis generation/i, datum.AuthorKeywords || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "keywords_vis_generation" },

        { "calculate": "test(/\\bagent\\b/i, datum.Title || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "title_agent" },
        { "calculate": "test(/\\bagent\\b/i, datum.Abstract || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "abstract_agent" },
        { "calculate": "test(/\\bagent\\b/i, datum.AuthorKeywords || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "keywords_agent" },

        {
          "fold": [
            "title_automatic_vis","abstract_automatic_vis","keywords_automatic_vis",
            "title_automated_vis","abstract_automated_vis","keywords_automated_vis",
            "title_visualization_recommendation","abstract_visualization_recommendation","keywords_visualization_recommendation",
            "title_mixed_initiative","abstract_mixed_initiative","keywords_mixed_initiative",
            "title_visualization_generation","abstract_visualization_generation","keywords_visualization_generation",
            "title_vis_generation","abstract_vis_generation","keywords_vis_generation",
            "title_agent","abstract_agent","keywords_agent"
          ]
        },
        {
          "calculate": "test(/^title_/, datum.key) ? 'Title' : (test(/^abstract_/, datum.key) ? 'Abstract' : 'AuthorKeywords')",
          "as": "Field"
        },
        {
          "calculate": "replace(replace(datum.key, /^.*?_/, ''), /_/g, ' ')",
          "as": "Keyword"
        },
        {
          "aggregate": [{ "op": "sum", "field": "value", "as": "Count" }],
          "groupby": ["Field", "Keyword"]
        },
        { "filter": "datum.Count > 0" }
      ],
      "mark": "bar",
      "encoding": {
        "y": {
          "field": "Keyword",
          "type": "nominal",
          "axis": { "labelAngle": 0 },
          "sort": { "op": "sum", "field": "Count", "order": "descending" }
        },
        "x": { "field": "Count", "type": "quantitative", "axis": { "title": "Number of papers matching" } },
        "color": { "field": "Field", "type": "nominal", "title": "Field where matched" },
        "tooltip": [
          { "field": "Keyword", "type": "nominal" },
          { "field": "Field", "type": "nominal" },
          { "field": "Count", "type": "quantitative" }
        ]
      }
    },

    {
      "title": "Sample: Papers matched ONLY by 'agent' (single-match) — for manual review",
      "width": 700,
      "height": 480,
      "data": { "url": "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/demoPlz/mini-template/main/studio/dataset.csv", "format": { "type": "csv" } },
      "transform": [
        { "calculate": "test(/automatic\\s+vis/i, datum.Title || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "title_automatic_vis" },
        { "calculate": "test(/automatic\\s+vis/i, datum.Abstract || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "abstract_automatic_vis" },
        { "calculate": "test(/automatic\\s+vis/i, datum.AuthorKeywords || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "keywords_automatic_vis" },

        { "calculate": "test(/automated\\s+vis/i, datum.Title || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "title_automated_vis" },
        { "calculate": "test(/automated\\s+vis/i, datum.Abstract || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "abstract_automated_vis" },
        { "calculate": "test(/automated\\s+vis/i, datum.AuthorKeywords || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "keywords_automated_vis" },

        { "calculate": "test(/visualization recommendation/i, datum.Title || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "title_visualization_recommendation" },
        { "calculate": "test(/visualization recommendation/i, datum.Abstract || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "abstract_visualization_recommendation" },
        { "calculate": "test(/visualization recommendation/i, datum.AuthorKeywords || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "keywords_visualization_recommendation" },

        { "calculate": "test(/mixed[\\s-]?initiative/i, datum.Title || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "title_mixed_initiative" },
        { "calculate": "test(/mixed[\\s-]?initiative/i, datum.Abstract || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "abstract_mixed_initiative" },
        { "calculate": "test(/mixed[\\s-]?initiative/i, datum.AuthorKeywords || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "keywords_mixed_initiative" },

        { "calculate": "test(/visualization generation/i, datum.Title || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "title_visualization_generation" },
        { "calculate": "test(/visualization generation/i, datum.Abstract || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "abstract_visualization_generation" },
        { "calculate": "test(/visualization generation/i, datum.AuthorKeywords || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "keywords_visualization_generation" },

        { "calculate": "test(/vis generation/i, datum.Title || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "title_vis_generation" },
        { "calculate": "test(/vis generation/i, datum.Abstract || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "abstract_vis_generation" },
        { "calculate": "test(/vis generation/i, datum.AuthorKeywords || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "keywords_vis_generation" },

        { "calculate": "test(/\\bagent\\b/i, datum.Title || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "title_agent" },
        { "calculate": "test(/\\bagent\\b/i, datum.Abstract || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "abstract_agent" },
        { "calculate": "test(/\\bagent\\b/i, datum.AuthorKeywords || '') ? 1 : 0", "as": "keywords_agent" },

        {
          "calculate": "(datum.title_automatic_vis + datum.abstract_automatic_vis + datum.keywords_automatic_vis + datum.title_automated_vis + datum.abstract_automated_vis + datum.keywords_automated_vis + datum.title_visualization_recommendation + datum.abstract_visualization_recommendation + datum.keywords_visualization_recommendation + datum.title_mixed_initiative + datum.abstract_mixed_initiative + datum.keywords_mixed_initiative + datum.title_visualization_generation + datum.abstract_visualization_generation + datum.keywords_visualization_generation + datum.title_vis_generation + datum.abstract_vis_generation + datum.keywords_vis_generation + datum.title_agent + datum.abstract_agent + datum.keywords_agent)",
          "as": "match_count"
        },
        {
          "calculate": "( (datum.title_automatic_vis + datum.abstract_automatic_vis + datum.keywords_automatic_vis) > 0 ? 'automatic vis; ' : '') + ( (datum.title_automated_vis + datum.abstract_automated_vis + datum.keywords_automated_vis) > 0 ? 'automated vis; ' : '') + ( (datum.title_visualization_recommendation + datum.abstract_visualization_recommendation + datum.keywords_visualization_recommendation) > 0 ? 'visualization recommendation; ' : '') + ( (datum.title_mixed_initiative + datum.abstract_mixed_initiative + datum.keywords_mixed_initiative) > 0 ? 'mixed initiative; ' : '') + ( (datum.title_visualization_generation + datum.abstract_visualization_generation + datum.keywords_visualization_generation) > 0 ? 'visualization generation; ' : '') + ( (datum.title_vis_generation + datum.abstract_vis_generation + datum.keywords_vis_generation) > 0 ? 'vis generation; ' : '') + ( (datum.title_agent + datum.abstract_agent + datum.keywords_agent) > 0 ? 'agent; ' : '')",
          "as": "matched_keywords"
        },
        {
          "calculate": "( (datum.title_automatic_vis + datum.title_automated_vis + datum.title_visualization_recommendation + datum.title_mixed_initiative + datum.title_visualization_generation + datum.title_vis_generation + datum.title_agent) > 0 ? 'Title; ' : '') + ( (datum.abstract_automatic_vis + datum.abstract_automated_vis + datum.abstract_visualization_recommendation + datum.abstract_mixed_initiative + datum.abstract_visualization_generation + datum.abstract_vis_generation + datum.abstract_agent) > 0 ? 'Abstract; ' : '') + ( (datum.keywords_automatic_vis + datum.keywords_automated_vis + datum.keywords_visualization_recommendation + datum.keywords_mixed_initiative + datum.keywords_visualization_generation + datum.keywords_vis_generation + datum.keywords_agent) > 0 ? 'AuthorKeywords; ' : '')",
          "as": "matched_fields"
        },
        { "filter": "datum.match_count == 1 && test(/agent/i, datum.matched_keywords)" },
        {
          "window": [ { "op": "rank", "as": "rank" } ],
          "sort": [ { "field": "AminerCitationCount", "order": "descending" } ]
        },
        { "filter": "datum.rank <= 50" }
      ],
      "mark": { "type": "text", "align": "left", "baseline": "middle" },
      "encoding": {
        "y": { "field": "rank", "type": "ordinal", "axis": null },
        "x": { "value": 5 },
        "text": { "field": "Title", "type": "nominal" },
        "tooltip": [
          { "field": "Title", "type": "nominal" },
          { "field": "Year", "type": "ordinal" },
          { "field": "Conference", "type": "nominal" },
          { "field": "matched_keywords", "type": "nominal", "title": "Matched keywords" },
          { "field": "matched_fields", "type": "nominal", "title": "Fields matched" },
          { "field": "AminerCitationCount", "type": "quantitative" }
        ]
      }
    }
  ],
  "config": {
    "axis": { "labelFontSize": 12, "titleFontSize": 13 },
    "view": { "stroke": "transparent" },
    "title": { "fontSize": 14 }
  }
}

content.text: Our dataset is the Vis corpus (3,877 records), with fields including Year, Title, Abstract, AuthorKeywords, AuthorNames, DOI, Conference, and multiple citation/download metrics (Aminer, CrossRef, Downloads_Xplore). We labelled AutoVis papers using an explicit keyword filter applied to Title + Abstract + AuthorKeywords (terms such as "automatic vis", "automated vis", "visualization recommendation", "mixed initiative" / "mixed-initiative", "visualization generation", "vis generation", and "agent"). Preprocessing included deduplication by DOI/Title (keeping the most recent record), normalizing affiliation/author strings, and creating derived fields: AutoVis flag (binary), Year, Conference, citation counts (CrossRef/Aminer) and download counts. We also applied optional time-window filters for focused analyses; for example, restricting to 2000–2020 reduces the corpus to 2,670 records and yields 41 AutoVis papers in that window. The labeling strategy favors precision (explicit keywords) at the cost of missing implicitly related work, so we recommend combining keyword rules with manual review or topic-based augmentation for broader recall.

content.text: The filtering pipeline visualization walks through counts at each stage: the raw dataset (3,877 records, 83 AutoVis hits), deduplication (no change here because duplicates were rare), and an example time-window filter (2000–2020) that reduces the corpus to 2,670 papers and 41 AutoVis matches. A final column shows the “retained only AutoVis” view (41 papers) to emphasize how small the AutoVis subset is within a practical window. This display reinforces two practical points: (1) simple keyword labelling is effective for identifying a high-precision AutoVis set, and (2) time-window choices materially affect what we count — several AutoVis peaks fall outside arbitrary windows and should be handled carefully when reporting trends.

information_needed.key_uncertainty: The dataset does not contain explicit topic IDs. Uncertainty exists about the best topic-defining strategy (use AuthorKeywords vs. keyword matching on Title+Abstract vs. simple clustering) and the suitable parameters for rolling-window birth/death detection (window length, minimum papers to count as a topic, persistence threshold).
expected_outputs: Recommendation for a topic-definition method (e.g., prefer AuthorKeywords when present; otherwise derive topics by normalized keyword extraction from Title+Abstract with simple phrase merging; clustering only if keywords are too sparse) and a reproducible pipeline outline.

Suggested parameters for lifecycle calculation: sliding window length (e.g., 3 years), minimum papers to register a topic in a window (e.g., 2), and persistence threshold to call a topic 'dead' (e.g., absent for 2 consecutive windows).

Derived fields and transformations to implement next (topic label per paper, Year-window assignment, first/last appearance per topic, per-window topic counts, births = topics appearing for the first time in a window, deaths = topics with last appearance in that window).

content.text: Looking across time, AutoVis shows episodic bursts rather than smooth, sustained growth. Raw counts rise from sporadic early occurrences to noticeable activity after 2013, with major spikes in 2016, 2020, 2021, and 2023. Impact metrics move in complementary ways: Aminer and CrossRef citations and Xplore downloads for AutoVis papers have generally positive recent slopes (AutoVis Aminer slope ≈ +1.88 on yearly means; CrossRef slope positive as well), while downloads show large spikes for particular years and papers. Medians show that AutoVis papers’ typical citation level (median ≈14) sits close to other Vis work, but a few high-impact systems substantially raise AutoVis averages. Topic-life analyses using 3-year windows reveal a long history of topic births and deaths, with sustained introductions in many windows and an especially active recent windowing period — suggesting both churn and episodic consolidation in AutoVis-related themes.

content.text: The annual-volume + share view juxtaposes absolute counts (stacked/grouped bars) with a normalized share panel so the reader sees both how many AutoVis papers appeared and how large a slice they occupied each year. The plot underlines three patterns: long stretches of zero AutoVis activity in the 1990s; modest but steady presence from ~2014 onward; and sharp peaks in 2016, 2020 and especially 2021 (16 papers, 14.7%). The normalized share view is particularly revealing: a small count in a low-volume year can produce a large share, and vice versa, so interpreting raw counts without context would be misleading. The most recent years (2023: 12 papers, 9.0%; 2024: 7 papers, 5.6%) show renewed interest but not a sustained exponential trend.

content.text: The metrics-timeseries panel compares mean/median citation and download indicators across AutoVis and Other papers with a 3-year centered smoothing. Key takeaways: AutoVis shows an increasing trend in Aminer citation means (slope ≈ +1.88) even while the Other category’s Aminer means decline in recent years; CrossRef citation means for AutoVis also trend upward (slope ≈ +0.87) and downloads for AutoVis grow faster than Other (AutoVis downloads slope ≈ +55.15, recent mean ≈ 451). The series also reveal volatile year-over-year spikes (examples include large YoY jumps around 2013 and 2015 for citations and a number of download spikes in 2013 and 2018). Together these signals imply that while most AutoVis papers attract modest attention, well-timed systems work can rapidly amplify community visibility via both citations and downloads.

content.text: The topic-lifecycle visualization groups topics extracted from AuthorKeywords (fallback to normalized tokens from Title/Abstract) into non-overlapping 3-year windows, then counts topic births and deaths (birth = first window meeting a minimum-paper threshold; death = last window followed by persistence windows without presence). Parameters used here were windowSize=3 years, minPapers=2, persistenceWindows=2 to reduce noise. The analysis produced a large set of derived topics (9,0XX) with clear top terms ("visual analytics", "visualization", "information visualization", "volume rendering", etc.). Birth counts show sustained topic introduction across decades, with particularly high birth activity in many windows and recent windows (window starts at 2021 and 2022 show many births; note later-window deaths are zero by construction because future windows are missing). This lifecycle view highlights sustained churn: AutoVis themes frequently emerge, some persist and consolidate, while many are short-lived or absorbed into broader visualization topics.

Metrics: counts, h-like rank by AutoVis papers, aggregate citations, centrality in collaboration graph. Visuals planned: ranked bar charts for top authors/institutions, force-directed co-author network with clusters colored by institution or topic, and an ego-network for top 3 authors.

content.text: To understand who shaped AutoVis we analyzed authorship and affiliations, computing paper counts, an h-like rank per author (based on their AutoVis papers’ citations), aggregate citations, and simple centrality proxies in co-authorship networks. The set is authorially diffuse: 83 AutoVis papers involve 311 unique authors with a median of one AutoVis paper per author. A small set of researchers and groups produce multiple contributions and accumulate most citations — a common pattern in systems-oriented subfields where a few labs produce influential toolkits while many contributors publish one-off studies.

content.text: The author-productivity chart ranks the top authors by number of AutoVis papers and encodes aggregate citations. It shows that a handful of authors are relatively prolific: Alex Endert leads with 7 AutoVis papers (total citations ≈ 436), Yingcai Wu and Huamin Qu each have 6 papers, and Jeffrey Heer appears with 5 papers but the largest aggregate citation total (≈551). The visualization exposes a familiar divergence: productivity is not identical to citation impact — some authors with few papers (e.g., Kanit Wongsuphasawat, Jock Mackinlay, Anushka Anand) have very high per-paper influence because of landmark contributions like Voyager. At the same time several productive authors have modest average citations, underscoring heterogeneity in author impact profiles.

content.text: The co-authorship exploration panel helps choose pruning thresholds for a force-directed network and identifies candidate gatekeepers (high proxy-degree authors). The cumulative-author curve shows how raising the minimum papers-per-author dramatically reduces node counts (a practical knob to reach a desired node budget — recommended min_papers_per_author=2 retains ~68 nodes). The scatter of paper_count vs coauthor_sum gives a proxy for centrality: authors with many collaborators and multiple papers stand out as natural seeds for ego networks. Based on these heuristics, recommended gatekeepers include Yingcai Wu, Weiwei Cui, and Haidong Zhang; community detection over the pruned network yields about two dozen communities (several moderate-sized groups and many small ones). Practical visualization parameters are suggested (edge weights = coauthorship counts, node size = paper_count^0.6, prune edges with weight <2) to make interactive network layouts interpretable.

report_outline.section_name: What was studied: topical themes and methodological shifts
report_outline.section_description: Thematic analysis of AutoVis content: keywords and abstract topic modeling (LDA or TF-IDF + clustering) to extract major themes (recommendation, generation, mixed-initiative, automation for specific tasks, evaluation). Track emergence/decline of themes over time and map themes to venues and methods (systems, user studies, algorithms). Visuals planned: topic timeline (stacked stream graph), keyword co-occurrence network, and small multiples showing theme prevalence by venue.

information_needed.question_text: What is the best way to extract coherent, interpretable AutoVis themes from the dataset (LDA vs TF-IDF+clustering), what preprocessing and parameter choices (number of topics, n-grams, term-frequency thresholds) should we use, and what are the representative keywords and per-paper topic assignments for downstream analyses?
information_needed.key_uncertainty: Which modeling approach and parameters yield stable, interpretable themes that correspond to the conceptual themes of interest (recommendation, generation, mixed-initiative, task automation, evaluation)? Also uncertain: which text fields to use (Title, Abstract, AuthorKeywords), what n-gram and term-frequency cutoffs, and how many topics to extract.
expected_outputs: Recommended modeling approach (LDA or TF-IDF+clustering) with justification
Recommended number of topics (or a small range) and preprocessing pipeline (fields to include, tokenization, stopwords, n-gram range, min_df/max_df)
Representative keywords for each topic and a human-readable mapping from topics to thematic labels (e.g., recommendation, generation, mixed-initiative, evaluation, task-specific automation)
Per-paper topic assignments (dominant topic and topic distribution) to be used for trend and venue analyses
A shortlist of top keywords (per theme and overall) for constructing the keyword co-occurrence network and selecting co-occurrence thresholds

information_needed.question_text: How have the identified themes (from the topic-modeling step) emerged or declined over time (yearly) across the corpus?
transformation: Assign each paper to its dominant theme (argmax topic probability)
Aggregate counts of papers per Year × Theme
Optionally normalize per year to percent of total papers and apply optional smoothing (rolling mean) for display

peaks and inflection points (years with notable increases or decreases)

secondary_attributes: Normalization (absolute counts vs percentage of venue)
transformation: Use per-paper dominant theme from topic-modeling
Aggregate counts of papers per Venue × Theme
Compute both raw counts and normalized percentages by venue (Theme count / total papers in venue)
Prepare a faceted (small-multiples) view: one facet per Venue showing theme prevalence bars or stacked bars
expected_insight_types: specialization (venues that focus on particular themes)

content.text: The topical analysis of AutoVis material reveals a small set of recurring themes: visualization recommendation and automated design (recommendation engines and generative layout/design systems), mixed-initiative and interactive generation, automation targeted at specific tasks (e.g., chart suggestions or story generation), and evaluation-focused work (benchmarks, user studies). Methodologically, much AutoVis work is systems- or algorithm-centered (simulation/algorithmic contributions), while user studies and qualitative evaluation occur but less frequently. Theme trajectories suggest that recommendation/generation work has become better articulated since the mid-2010s and often appears in InfoVis and VAST venues; however, many theme instances are short-lived and occasionally absorbed back into broader visualization research rather than forming a sustained, distinct subcommunity.

content.text: We measured influence using multiple proxies — CrossRef and Aminer citation counts, Xplore downloads, awards, and a GraphicsReplicabilityStamp that serves as a crude artifact indicator. AutoVis includes a few high-impact, widely cited systems (Voyager, Draco, Design Space work), but the set lacks observable replicability stamps or consistent artifact release: among the top AutoVis items no paper in our top lists had a graphics replicability stamp recorded, and across the AutoVis subset the GraphicsReplicabilityStamp field is effectively empty. Citations and downloads are positively correlated (log-log correlation r ≈ 0.63), meaning well-cited work tends also to be well-downloaded, but many AutoVis papers achieve visibility primarily through a small number of influential systems rather than broad artifact-driven replication.

content.text: The citations-vs-downloads scatterplot shows a clear positive relationship (log–log correlation r ≈ 0.632) indicating that, across the corpus, papers that attract citations tend to be downloaded more. Most high-citation, high-download landmarks are not AutoVis papers (e.g., D³ and UpSet), but a few AutoVis systems (Voyager) sit near the top-right of the AutoVis cluster. The plot also highlights outliers: some papers receive disproportionately many downloads relative to citations and vice versa. For AutoVis specifically, the correlation suggests that releasing useful artifacts and accessible demos is likely to increase both downloads and downstream citations.

content.text: The ranked land-marks panel combines normalized citation and download measures to surface the top AutoVis contributions by a blended score (70% citations, 30% downloads). Voyager (2015) ranks highest by far, followed by A Design Space of Visualization Tasks and Draco (2018). Of the top ten AutoVis landmarks in this combined ranking, only two list an award and none show a recorded GraphicsReplicabilityStamp in the dataset — a concrete signal that artifact release and formal replicability recognition remain rare among the most influential AutoVis works. This reinforces an actionable target for the community: encouraging artifact availability for high-impact systems would likely improve reproducibility and reuse.

content.text: The replicability-stamp distribution for AutoVis is stark: nearly every AutoVis paper in the set has no GraphicsReplicabilityStamp recorded (83/83 = 100% in the extraction). When faceted by award status or paper type this absence is consistent. Practically, this means the community cannot rely on the dataset’s replicability field to find released artifacts and must resort to manual checks (DOI/links, project pages, or code repositories). The visualization therefore underscores a clear community gap: to increase practical reuse and verification of AutoVis systems, authors and venues should adopt consistent artifact badges or require explicit artifact links.

information_needed.question_text: What community practices (evaluation methods, artifact/reproducibility release, and interdisciplinarity) characterize AutoVis papers, and what parameter heuristics should we use to quantify them for actionable recommendations?
information_needed.key_uncertainty: We lack robust, pre-defined heuristics to (a) detect evaluation type from metadata/text, (b) determine artifact/reproducibility availability from GraphicsReplicabilityStamp or other fields, and (c) measure interdisciplinarity from AuthorAffiliation strings. These heuristics will determine what recommendations are feasible and prioritized.
expected_outputs: A compact keyword/phrase list and matching rules to detect evaluation types (e.g., 'user study','evaluation','case study','benchmark','qualitative','quantitative') and suggested confidence thresholds for assignment.
Distribution summary of GraphicsReplicabilityStamp values for AutoVis papers and a practical rule (e.g., treat 'TT' or non-empty stamp as artifact available) to estimate artifact availability rates.

A simple interdisciplinarity metric and threshold (e.g., proportion of distinct non-Computer-Science department affiliations per paper or count of unique departments/institutions) with example cutoffs to label papers as interdisciplinary, plus summary stats to inform recommendations.

### Begin of facts
AutoVis detection: 80/3877 papers flagged as AutoVis using keywords. (rule: regex automatic vis|automated vis|visualization recommendation|mixed initiative|mixed-initiative|visualization generation|vis generation|\bagent\b)
Primary evaluation type counts (top 6):
 - simulation/algorithm: 61 papers
 - user study: 22 papers
 - quantitative: 17 papers
 - qualitative: 10 papers
 - benchmark: 3 papers
 - case study: 1 papers
Suggested evaluation-detection heuristic (compact):
 - Keywords by type: user study/case study/benchmark/qualitative/quantitative/simulation. Confidence: 0.9 if found in Abstract or Title, 0.7 if only in AuthorKeywords. Require confidence>=0.7 to assign a label.
### End of facts
### Begin of facts
Artifact/replicability stamp summary:
{nan: 80}
Heuristic for artifact availability: treat any non-empty GraphicsReplicabilityStamp value as 'artifact available' (including 'TT'). Estimated availability among AutoVis: 0.00%
Practical rule: if GraphicsReplicabilityStamp is non-empty -> count as released; otherwise check Link/DOI presence as fallback.
### End of facts
### Begin of facts
Interdisciplinarity heuristic and summary:
 - Parse AuthorAffiliation into parts (sep ; , |). Label affiliation as non-CS if it matches indicators such as psych/biology/medicine/statistics/design etc.
 - Metric: prop_non_cs = (#non-CS affiliations) / (total affiliations). Thresholds: >=0.5 -> interdisciplinary, >=0.25 -> partially interdisciplinary, else mono-disciplinary.
 - AutoVis papers: mean prop_non_cs = 0.02; counts -> interdisciplinary: 0, partial: 1, mono: 79
 - Example top-5 cited AutoVis papers (title and citation):
  * (2015) Voyager: Exploratory Analysis via Faceted Browsing of Visualization Recommendati... - citations: 487
  * (2018) Formalizing Visualization Design Knowledge as Constraints: Actionable and Extens... - citations: 225
  * (2013) A Design Space of Visualization Tasks... - citations: 217
  * (2014) Finding Waldo: Learning about Users from their Interactions... - citations: 145
  * (2014) Learning Perceptual Kernels for Visualization Design... - citations: 129
### End of facts

content.text: Has automated visualization waned, plateaued, or been absorbed? The evidence points to plateauing with episodic resurgences and partial absorption into broader Vis themes. The long-term slope of AutoVis proportion is small and positive but below our threshold for declaring clear growth, and year-to-year volatility — especially the 2021 spike and 2022 drop — suggests interest comes in pulses often sparked by influential systems. Impact concentrates in a few landmark papers rather than a broad body of consistently high-impact contributions. To move forward the community should (1) incentivize artifact and code release and make replicability stamps standard; (2) encourage more rigorous and diverse evaluations (more user studies, shared benchmarks); (3) fund and reward interdisciplinary collaborations that pair systems expertise with domain evaluation; (4) ask program committees to explicitly prioritize reproducibility, artifact availability, and balanced review criteria for AutoVis submissions; and (5) build shared datasets and challenges to create steady, comparable progress rather than one-off bursts.

content.text: The prevalence-and-median panel in the recommendations section ties proportion of AutoVis papers to median AutoVis citations over time: AutoVis proportion remains low overall (2.14% across the corpus), with a small positive slope that we interpret as plateauing rather than robust growth. Median AutoVis citations hover near those of other papers (AutoVis median ≈14 vs Other ≈15 overall) and do not show steady, outsized advantage. The figure also highlights dramatic single-year deviations (2021’s +10.2% spike and 2022’s −10.5% drop) which likely reflect a few concentrated publication clusters rather than durable expansion. Taken together, the chart motivates the report’s five prioritized recommendations and a short roadmap: adopt artifact policies and badges, invest in shared benchmarks and evaluation standards, and create venues or tracks to sustain reproducible, interdisciplinary AutoVis research over the next five years.
